ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Cannot describe how much I learned about how to read, analyze, and critique political science papers. Didac is demanding, but in the most constructive way possiblehe asks you to think better and do better, and he does provide the tools for you to do so, from taking the time to break down particularly quantitative papers to offering feedback on writing. This class teaches you so much about why states form, what they do, and how to measure what they arewhich is super relevant to anything in the social sciences, and is worth learning about even if you're coming from a completely different field.
Theories of state formation and state building
I developed my understanding and theoretical knowldege about state formation, state building, and state capacity.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: No weaknesses. There is a ton of work, but it's worth it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Without any reservations. A contender for the single best course I've taken at Yale.
Yes. Best course I have taken.
